p: Delays in reporting are often structurally decomposed into a ( T x D) dimensional “reporting triangle,” where T is the most recent week (“now”) and D is the maximum reporting delay, in weeks, observed in the data. The data are right-truncated, since at any given week t, delays longer than T–t cannot be observed. For example, at week t = T, only the cases reported with delay d = 0 are observable; cases reported with longer delays (i.e. 1- or 2-week delays, d = 1 or d = 2) will be known in future weeks. In S6 Table, we present an example of the reporting triangle using ILI data.
